writing_prompt: When Arthur stumbles upon the scars Merlin has been hiding, he demands answers—but the truth behind them reveals more than either of them expected, leaving their bond forever changed.
story:
Arthur had always known there was something different about Merlin. He couldn't quite put his finger on it, but there was an air of mystery around the young warlock that Arthur found both intriguing and infuriating. Merlin was loyal to a fault, always there when Arthur needed him, always ready with a quick retort or a reassuring smile. But beneath the surface, Arthur sensed a deeper, more complex story that Merlin had never shared.

It was a warm summer evening when Arthur's suspicions were finally confirmed. The knights had returned from a grueling patrol, weary and covered in dirt. Merlin, as usual, was there to greet them, his ever-present grin plastered on his face despite the late hour.

"Welcome back, Sire," Merlin said, taking the reins of Arthur's horse and leading it towards the stables. "I trust the patrol was uneventful?"

Arthur dismounted with a grunt, rubbing the back of his neck. "Uneventful, yes. But tiring. I could use a bath and a good night's sleep."

Merlin chuckled. "Well, you're in luck. I've already prepared the bath for you. All you need to do is relax."

Arthur raised an eyebrow. "Prepared the bath, have you? You're getting better at this servant business, Merlin."

Merlin's grin widened. "I aim to please, Sire."

Arthur followed Merlin to his chambers, where a steaming bath awaited him. He peeled off his armor and tunic, sighing in relief as the warm water enveloped his tired muscles. Merlin busied himself with tidying up the room, ever the diligent servant.

"Merlin," Arthur called, his voice muffled by the water. "Come here for a moment."

Merlin approached, curiosity etched on his face. "Yes, Sire?"

Arthur gestured for him to sit on the edge of the bath. "I've been meaning to ask you something."

Merlin's brow furrowed. "What is it?"

"Those scars on your back," Arthur said, his tone serious. "I've seen them before, when you were changing your shirt. Where did they come from?"

Merlin's face paled, and he quickly averted his gaze. "It's nothing, Sire. Just old injuries."

Arthur wasn't satisfied with that answer. "Old injuries? From what?"

Merlin hesitated, his eyes darting around the room as if searching for an escape. "It's... complicated."

Arthur reached out, gently placing a hand on Merlin's arm. "Merlin, you can trust me. Please, tell me the truth."

Merlin took a deep breath, his shoulders slumping in defeat. "Alright. But you have to promise not to tell anyone."

Arthur nodded, his curiosity piqued. "I promise."

Merlin took another deep breath, his gaze fixed on the floor. "The scars are from... magic. When I was a child, my magic was wild and uncontrollable. I didn't know how to control it, and it would lash out unpredictably. My mother did her best to help me, but it wasn't enough. I hurt myself, and others, more times than I can count."

Arthur's eyes widened in shock. "Magic? You have magic?"

Merlin nodded, his expression pained. "Yes. I've always had it. And I've always had to hide it. If anyone in Camelot knew, I'd be executed."

Arthur's mind raced as he tried to process this revelation. Merlin, his loyal servant and friend, was a sorcerer. A sorcerer who had risked his life time and time again to protect Arthur and Camelot.

"Why didn't you tell me?" Arthur asked, his voice barely above a whisper.

Merlin looked up, his eyes filled with sorrow. "Because I was afraid. Afraid of what you would think. Afraid of what would happen to me. But most of all, I was afraid of losing you."

Arthur's heart ached at the raw vulnerability in Merlin's voice. He had always known there was more to Merlin than met the eye, but he had never imagined the depth of the secrets his friend had been carrying.

"Merlin," Arthur said softly, his hand still resting on Merlin's arm. "You don't have to be afraid anymore. I'm not going to turn you in. You're my friend, and I trust you."

Merlin's eyes filled with tears, and he quickly wiped them away. "Thank you, Arthur. You have no idea how much that means to me."

Arthur offered a small smile. "I think I have some idea."

Merlin chuckled, a sound that was both relieved and bittersweet. "There's more to the story, you know. The scars... they're not just from my childhood. I've gotten more of them over the years, trying to protect you and Camelot."

Arthur's brow furrowed. "Protecting me? How?"

Merlin sighed, running a hand through his hair. "There have been countless times when magic was the only thing standing between you and certain death. I've used my magic to save you more times than I can count. But each time I do, it takes a toll on me. The scars are a reminder of that."

Arthur's mind reeled as he thought back to all the times he had narrowly escaped danger, all the miraculous saves that had seemed like pure luck. It had been Merlin all along, using his magic to keep Arthur safe.

"Why didn't you tell me?" Arthur asked again, his voice filled with a mixture of anger and sorrow.

"Because I didn't want you to see me as a monster," Merlin replied, his voice trembling. "I didn't want you to hate me."

Arthur's grip on Merlin's arm tightened. "I could never hate you, Merlin. You're my friend. My brother. And I owe you my life."

Merlin looked up, his eyes shining with gratitude. "Thank you, Arthur. That means more to me than you'll ever know."

Arthur pulled Merlin into a tight embrace, holding him close. "We'll figure this out together," he murmured. "You're not alone anymore."

Merlin clung to Arthur, his heart finally feeling a sense of peace that had eluded him for so long. He had always feared that his magic would be the end of him, that it would drive a wedge between him and the people he cared about. But in Arthur's embrace, he found hope. Hope that their bond could withstand anything, even the truth.

As they pulled apart, Arthur looked at Merlin with a newfound determination. "We need to be careful," he said. "If anyone finds out about your magic, it could be dangerous for both of us."

Merlin nodded. "I know. I've been careful all these years, and I'll continue to be."

Arthur squeezed Merlin's shoulder. "Good. Now, let's get you some rest. You look like you could use it."

Merlin chuckled, a genuine smile spreading across his face. "You too, Arthur. You too."

As they settled into a comfortable silence, Arthur couldn't help but feel a sense of awe at the strength and resilience of his friend. Merlin had faced unimaginable challenges, all while keeping his true self hidden. But now, with the truth out in the open, Arthur felt a renewed sense of purpose. He would protect Merlin, just as Merlin had protected him. And together, they would face whatever challenges lay ahead.

The days that followed were filled with a newfound sense of camaraderie between Arthur and Merlin. They worked together seamlessly, their bond stronger than ever. Arthur found himself watching Merlin more closely, noticing the subtle ways his magic manifested. It was as if a veil had been lifted, revealing the true depth of Merlin's power and the lengths he went to in order to keep Camelot safe.

One evening, as they sat by the fire in Arthur's chambers, Merlin spoke up. "There's something else you should know, Arthur."

Arthur looked up from the book he was reading, curiosity piqued. "What is it?"

Merlin took a deep breath, his hands fidgeting nervously. "I've had visions. Visions of the future. And in those visions, I've seen you becoming the greatest king Camelot has ever known. But it's not just you, Arthur. It's us, together. You and me, working side by side to bring peace and prosperity to the kingdom."

Arthur's eyes widened in surprise. "Visions of the future? You've seen this?"

Merlin nodded. "Yes. And I believe it's our destiny. But we have to be careful. There are forces out there that would do anything to stop us."

Arthur's mind raced as he processed this new information. "Destiny," he murmured, the word heavy with meaning. "I suppose I always knew there was something special about you, Merlin. But this... this is beyond anything I could have imagined."

Merlin smiled, a glimmer of hope in his eyes. "It's a lot to take in, I know. But I believe in us, Arthur. I believe we can make a difference."

Arthur reached out, taking Merlin's hand in his own. "I believe in us too, Merlin. And I promise, no matter what happens, we'll face it together."

Merlin's heart swelled with gratitude and love for his friend. In that moment, he knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, they would face them with unwavering determination and strength. They were bound by destiny, and their bond would only grow stronger with each passing day.

As the fire crackled and the night grew darker, Arthur and Merlin sat side by side, ready to face whatever the future held. They were more than just a prince and his servant. They were friends, brothers, and partners in a destiny that would shape the fate of Camelot.

And together, they would forge a legacy that would be remembered for generations to come.

writing_prompt: A scruffy young raven, outcast by her kin, takes up residence in your chambers, much to the dismay of your court. But as the bird grows into a striking and mischievous companion, you realize she may be more than just a pet—she's family.
story:
Thorin Oakenshield had never been particularly fond of birds. They were fine enough in their own right—majestic in flight, symbols of freedom and strength—but they also had a way of making a mess of his kingdom's statues and roofs. Ravens, however, were an exception. They were the bearers of news, the watchers from the skies, and had a long history with the line of Durin. So it was with mixed feelings that he discovered a scruffy young raven perched on the windowsill of his chambers one crisp autumn morning.

The bird was small, bedraggled, and clearly an outcast. Its feathers were ruffled and uneven, as though it had been in several fights, and its eyes were sharp but wary. Thorin approached cautiously, the raven watching him with an intensity that belied its age.

"I see you've decided to make yourself at home," Thorin muttered, more to himself than the bird. The raven tilted its head, seemingly understanding him. He shook his head and turned away, thinking the creature would leave as soon as it realized there was no food to be had here.

But the raven stayed.

Over the next few days, Thorin found the bird in his chambers more often than not. It perched on his desk as he worked, its beady eyes following the quill in his hand. It sat on the back of his chair as he dressed, its feathers brushing against his hair. It even hopped onto the edge of his bed at night, its presence a small, warm weight in the darkness.

The court was less than pleased. Dwalin, ever the pragmatist, suggested they shoo the bird away before it caused any trouble. Balin, more diplomatic, proposed they find a way to care for it properly, perhaps in the aviary with the other birds. But Thorin found himself reluctant to send the raven away. There was something about the creature that resonated with him—a kindred spirit, perhaps, another outcast trying to find its place in the world.

As the weeks passed, the raven grew stronger and more confident. Its feathers smoothed out, becoming sleek and glossy, and it began to explore the halls of Erebor with a mischievous curiosity. It stole trinkets from the dwarves, hiding them in Thorin's chambers, and squawked loudly whenever anyone tried to enter without permission. The court quickly learned to respect the bird's territory, and Thorin couldn't help but be amused by the raven's antics.

One evening, as Thorin sat by the fire, the raven landed on his shoulder. It nuzzled its beak against his cheek, a gesture of affection that took him by surprise. He reached up to stroke its feathers, marveling at how much the bird had changed since that first day on the windowsill.

"You've certainly made yourself at home," he said softly. The raven croaked in agreement, settling more comfortably on his shoulder. Thorin smiled, feeling a warmth in his chest that he hadn't felt in a long time.

It was then that he realized the raven was more than just a pet. She was family.

The court eventually came to accept the raven's presence, though not without some grumbling. Dwalin, in particular, seemed to develop a grudging respect for the bird, especially after she dive-bombed a visiting envoy who had been particularly rude. Balin, ever the peacemaker, made sure she was well-fed and cared for, even going so far as to construct a small perch in Thorin's chambers.

As the months turned into years, the raven became a fixture in Erebor. She was a guardian, a companion, and a symbol of resilience. She accompanied Thorin on his daily rounds, perched on his shoulder like a living cloak, and even sat in on council meetings, her sharp eyes taking in everything.

One winter's night, as a fierce storm raged outside, Thorin found himself reflecting on the journey that had brought them to this point. The reclamation of Erebor had been a hard-fought battle, fraught with loss and heartache. The scars of the past still lingered, both in the kingdom and in his heart. But the raven had shown him that even in the darkest of times, there was hope and the possibility of new beginnings.

The fire crackled in the hearth, casting flickering shadows on the stone walls. Thorin sat in his favorite chair, the raven nestled against his neck. He stroked her feathers absently, lost in thought. The storm outside seemed a distant echo compared to the warmth and peace he felt in that moment.

"You've given me more than you know," he whispered to the raven. She croaked softly, as if in agreement, and nuzzled closer.

It was then that Thorin realized the true depth of their bond. The raven had not only become his companion but a part of his heart. She had brought joy and laughter back into his life, something he had long thought lost. In her, he saw a reflection of his own journey—a tale of survival, resilience, and the unbreakable bonds of family.

The raven stayed with Thorin for many years, through times of peace and times of strife. She was a constant presence, a reminder of the strength that could be found in even the most unlikely of places. And as Thorin grew older, he took comfort in knowing that he had never truly been alone.

One spring morning, as the first rays of sunlight filtered through the windows, Thorin awoke to find the raven perched on the edge of his bed. She looked at him with those sharp, knowing eyes, and he felt a pang of sadness. He knew that their time together was drawing to a close.

"Thank you," he said softly, his voice thick with emotion. The raven croaked in response, her eyes never leaving his.

In the days that followed, Thorin's health began to decline. The court grew worried, but Thorin remained at peace. He had lived a full life, and he was ready to join his ancestors. The raven stayed by his side, her presence a source of comfort and strength.

On the night of his passing, the raven flew from Erebor, her wings cutting through the night sky like a shadow. She carried with her the memory of a king who had found solace in her companionship, and the knowledge that she had made a difference in his life.

The dwarves of Erebor mourned the loss of their king, but they also celebrated his life and the legacy he had left behind. And in the years to come, they told the tale of the scruffy young raven who had found a home in the heart of a king.

The raven returned to Erebor, her feathers now silvered with age. She perched on the statue of Thorin Oakenshield, her eyes scanning the horizon. She had seen many things in her long life, but the bond she had shared with Thorin was something she would never forget.

As the sun set over the Lonely Mountain, casting a golden glow on the land below, the raven let out a mournful cry. It was a call of remembrance, a tribute to the king who had taken her in and shown her the meaning of family.

In the years that followed, the dwarves of Erebor continued to thrive. They rebuilt their kingdom, forging new alliances and strengthening old bonds. And through it all, the memory of Thorin Oakenshield and his raven lived on, a testament to the enduring power of love and loyalty.

The raven, now old and wise, continued to watch over Erebor, her presence a silent guardian of the kingdom she had come to call home. She had found her place in the world, and in doing so, had helped Thorin find his as well.

And so, the tale of the scruffy young raven and the king who had given her a home became a part of the lore of Erebor. It was a story of resilience, of new beginnings, and of the unbreakable bonds of family.

In the end, it was a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope. And that sometimes, family is found in the most unexpected of places.

writing_prompt: On the coldest night of the year, Merlin braves the frost to gather a rare herb, only to find himself summoned to Arthur's chambers. What begins as a simple scolding over his lack of winter gear turns into an unexpectedly tender moment by the fire.
story:
The air outside was sharp and biting, every breath Merlin took felt like inhaling shards of ice. The cold wrapped around him, relentless and unforgiving, as he trudged through the snow-covered forest. His cloak, though thick and sturdy, did little to stave off the chill that had settled into his bones. Gaius had sent him on this errand, desperate for the rare herb that only grew on the coldest nights of the year. Merlin had hoped he might find it quickly, but the frost-covered landscape offered no such mercy. Each step felt heavier than the last, his boots sinking into the snow with a crunch that echoed through the silent woods.

Finally, after what felt like hours, Merlin spotted the distinctive blue glow of the herb nestled among the roots of an ancient oak tree. He let out a sigh of relief, his breath misting in the frigid air, and carefully knelt to gather it. His fingers, numb and clumsy from the cold, fumbled with the delicate leaves. Once he had secured the precious plant in his pouch, he stood up, wincing as his stiff joints protested the movement.

The journey back to Camelot was no easier. The wind had picked up, howling through the trees and whipping around him with a ferocity that made his eyes water. By the time he reached the castle gates, his entire body felt frozen, his limbs heavy and uncooperative. The guards gave him curious looks as he stumbled inside, but he barely registered their presence, his mind focused solely on getting warm.

He made his way to Gaius' chambers, his movements slow and deliberate. The warmth of the castle was a welcome relief, but it did little to thaw the chill that had settled deep within him. He handed the herb to Gaius, who took one look at him and frowned.

"Merlin, you look half-dead," the physician said, his voice filled with concern. "You should have dressed more warmly before going out in this weather."

Merlin managed a weak smile. "I'll be fine, Gaius. Just need to warm up a bit."

Gaius shook his head, his expression stern. "You need to take better care of yourself, Merlin. Now, go and get some rest. I'll prepare the herb."

Merlin nodded, too exhausted to argue. He made his way to his own small room, intending to collapse into bed and sleep off the cold. But before he could reach the door, a familiar voice echoed through the corridor.

"Merlin! Where have you been?"

He turned to see Arthur striding towards him, his expression a mix of annoyance and concern. Merlin straightened up, trying to hide the shivers that still wracked his body.

"I was out gathering an herb for Gaius," he explained, his voice hoarse.

Arthur's frown deepened. "In this weather? Are you mad?"

Merlin shrugged, trying to appear nonchalant. "It had to be done."

Arthur shook his head, exasperated. "Come with me. We need to talk."

Merlin followed Arthur to his chambers, wondering what he had done this time to earn the prince's ire. The warmth of the room was a stark contrast to the freezing cold outside, and Merlin couldn't help but sigh in relief as the heat began to seep into his skin. Arthur closed the door behind them and turned to face him, arms crossed.

"Do you have any idea how dangerous it is to be out in this cold without proper gear?" Arthur demanded, his voice sharp.

Merlin blinked, taken aback by the intensity of Arthur's concern. "I was careful," he said, though he knew it was a weak defense.

Arthur's expression softened slightly, but his eyes remained stern. "You could have frozen to death, Merlin. You need to take better care of yourself."

Merlin opened his mouth to respond, but Arthur held up a hand to stop him. "Sit by the fire. You look like you're about to collapse."

Merlin hesitated for a moment before obeying, sinking into one of the chairs by the hearth. The flames danced and flickered, casting a warm glow over the room. Arthur moved to a chest in the corner and rummaged through it, eventually producing a thick, fur-lined cloak. He draped it over Merlin's shoulders, the weight and warmth of it almost overwhelming.

"Thank you," Merlin murmured, pulling the cloak tighter around himself.

Arthur nodded, his expression still serious. "You need to be more careful, Merlin. You're no good to anyone if you get yourself killed."

Merlin looked up at Arthur, surprised by the genuine concern in his voice. "I didn't realize you cared so much," he said, a small smile playing at his lips.

Arthur rolled his eyes, but there was a hint of a smile on his own face. "Of course I care, you idiot. You're my servant. I can't have you dropping dead on me."

Merlin chuckled, the sound warming the room even more than the fire. "I'll try to remember that."

Arthur sat down in the chair opposite him, his expression softening further. "Seriously, Merlin. You need to take better care of yourself. I don't want to lose you."

Merlin's heart skipped a beat at the sincerity in Arthur's words. He had always known that Arthur cared about him, but moments like this made it abundantly clear. "I'll be more careful," he promised, his voice quiet.

They sat in companionable silence for a while, the crackling of the fire the only sound in the room. Merlin could feel the warmth slowly returning to his body, the chill of the night's journey melting away. He watched as Arthur stared into the flames, his usually stern features softened by the firelight.

"Arthur," Merlin began hesitantly, "thank you."

Arthur glanced over at him, raising an eyebrow. "For what?"

"For caring," Merlin said simply.

Arthur's expression softened even more, and he nodded. "You're welcome, Merlin."

Another silence settled over them, but this one was different. It was filled with an unspoken understanding, a bond that had been forged through countless trials and tribulations. Merlin had always known that Arthur was more than just his prince, more than just his friend. He was someone who saw him, truly saw him, and cared for him in a way that few others did.

As the fire crackled and the warmth enveloped them, Merlin felt a sense of peace settle over him. The coldest night of the year had brought him more than just a rare herb; it had brought him a moment of unexpected tenderness, a reminder of the bond he shared with Arthur. And in that moment, he knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, they would face them together.

The next day, the cold was still present, but it felt less biting with the memory of the warmth from the night before lingering in Merlin's mind. He went about his duties with a renewed sense of purpose, the fur-lined cloak Arthur had given him draped over his shoulders. The castle was bustling with activity, everyone trying to stay warm and keep the fires burning.

As Merlin made his way through the corridors, he couldn't help but notice the small gestures of kindness that seemed to be everywhere. Gwen was helping a young servant boy who had slipped on the ice, her gentle smile reassuring him. Gaius was distributing extra blankets to those who needed them, his wise eyes twinkling with warmth.

Even Arthur, who was usually so focused on his duties, took the time to check on the knights and ensure they were properly equipped for the cold. It was as if the harshness of the weather had brought out the best in everyone, a reminder of the strength and resilience of Camelot's people.

Merlin found himself smiling more often, the memory of the tender moment by the fire with Arthur a constant source of warmth. He knew that their bond was something special, something that went beyond the roles of prince and servant. It was a friendship built on trust, loyalty, and a deep understanding of each other's strengths and weaknesses.

As the days passed, the cold began to relent, the harsh frost giving way to the promise of spring. The rare herb Merlin had gathered proved to be exactly what Gaius needed, and the patients who had been suffering from the winter ailments began to recover. The castle slowly returned to its usual rhythm, the warmth of the fires and the camaraderie of its inhabitants a testament to their resilience.

One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the sky was painted in hues of pink and gold, Merlin found himself once again in Arthur's chambers. This time, it was not out of necessity or duty, but simply to share a moment of quiet companionship.

Arthur was seated by the fire, a thoughtful expression on his face as he stared into the flames. Merlin took a seat opposite him, the familiarity of the scene bringing a sense of comfort. They sat in silence for a while, the only sound the crackling of the fire and the occasional pop of the logs.

Eventually, Arthur spoke, his voice soft. "Do you ever wonder what the future holds, Merlin?"

Merlin looked up, surprised by the question. He had spent so much time focusing on the present, on the challenges and dangers they faced, that he rarely allowed himself to think too far ahead. "Sometimes," he admitted. "But I try not to dwell on it too much. There's so much we have to deal with in the here and now."

Arthur nodded, his gaze still fixed on the flames. "I know. But sometimes I can't help but wonder what kind of king I'll be, what kind of kingdom I'll leave behind."

Merlin studied Arthur's profile, the firelight casting shadows on his face. He had always known that Arthur was destined for greatness, but he also knew that the path to that greatness would not be easy. "You'll be a great king, Arthur," he said with conviction. "You care about your people, and you have the strength and wisdom to lead them."

Arthur turned to look at him, a small smile playing at his lips. "You have a lot of faith in me, Merlin."

Merlin returned the smile, his eyes filled with sincerity. "I always have. And I always will."

They sat in silence once more, the unspoken bond between them stronger than ever. Merlin knew that no matter what the future held, they would face it together. The coldest night of the year had brought them closer, a reminder of the warmth and strength that could be found in even the harshest of times.

As the fire continued to burn, casting its warm glow over the room, Merlin felt a deep sense of contentment. The challenges they faced were many, but the bond they shared was unbreakable. And in that bond, he found the strength to face whatever lay ahead.

The days turned to weeks, and the weeks to months. The cold of winter gave way to the warmth of spring, and with it came new challenges and adventures. But through it all, the memory of that coldest night and the unexpected tenderness by the fire remained a constant source of strength for Merlin.

He often found himself thinking back to that night, the warmth of the fire and Arthur's genuine concern for him a reminder of the bond they shared. It was a bond that went beyond duty and obligation, a friendship built on trust, loyalty, and a deep understanding of each other's strengths and weaknesses.

As the seasons changed and the years passed, Merlin and Arthur faced countless trials and tribulations. But no matter what challenges came their way, they faced them together, their bond unbreakable and their friendship unwavering.

And so, on the coldest night of the year, Merlin had found more than just a rare herb. He had found a moment of unexpected tenderness, a reminder of the strength and warmth that could be found in even the harshest of times. And in that moment, he had found a sense of peace and contentment that would stay with him for the rest of his days.

writing_prompt: When Bilbo Baggins left the Shire for his grand adventure, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins saw an opportunity to claim Bag End for herself. But when news of Bilbo's unexpected fate reaches Hobbiton, her plans—and her pride—are thrown into chaos.
story:
The green, rolling hills of Hobbiton were peaceful, as always, when the morning sun cast its golden light over the landscape. But inside Bag End, the air was anything but calm. Lobelia Sackville-Baggins stood in the grand hallway, her sharp eyes glinting with a mix of triumph and vexation.

"Do you see it, Lotho?" she snapped, waving a hand at the spacious interior. "This, all of this should be ours. And yet, that dratted Bilbo has the audacity to run off, leaving it all behind without so much as a by-your-leave."

Lotho, her son, shrugged, his lanky frame leaning against the doorframe. "He's gone, Mother. He's probably never coming back. That means Bag End will be ours, eventually."

Lobelia's lips thinned into a tight line. "Eventually isn't good enough. We need to make sure it's sooner rather than later. We need to make sure the will is read and the property is transferred without delay."

The news of Bilbo's departure had spread like wildfire through Hobbiton, and Lobelia had seen her chance. She'd always coveted Bag End, with its perfectly manicured gardens and prime location atop the Hill. And now, with Bilbo off on some foolhardy adventure, she was determined to claim it for herself.

But her plans were thrown into disarray when a messenger arrived from Rivendell, bearing news that Bilbo had not met some unfortunate end as she had hoped, but had instead been instrumental in aiding the dwarves in reclaiming Erebor. Worse yet, he was returning home.

Lobelia's face turned an alarming shade of red as she read the letter. "How dare he!" she fumed. "How dare he survive and come back to ruin everything?"

Lotho looked up from the table where he was polishing a silver fork. "What does it say, Mother?"

"It says," Lobelia hissed, "that Bilbo is on his way back to the Shire, and that he is now considered a hero by the dwarves. A hero! Can you imagine?" She threw the letter down in disgust. "We need to act quickly, Lotho. We need to make sure Bag End is ours before he gets back."

Lotho scratched his head. "But how are we going to do that? We can't just take it."

Lobelia's eyes narrowed. "Oh, but we can. We just need to be clever about it. We'll claim that Bilbo abandoned Bag End, that he left it to us in his will. No one will question it if we present it properly."

And so, Lobelia set her plan into motion. She spread rumors throughout Hobbiton that Bilbo had intended to leave Bag End to her and Lotho, that he had no intention of returning. She even forged a will, complete with Bilbo's signature, to support her claims.

But as the days passed and Bilbo's return drew nearer, Lobelia's anxiety grew. She knew that if Bilbo walked through the door of Bag End, all her plans would be for naught. She needed to find a way to keep him from coming back.

As fate would have it, an opportunity presented itself one evening when she overheard a conversation between two hobbits at the Green Dragon Inn.

"Did you hear? Bilbo's stopped in Bree on his way back. Some trouble with brigands, they say," one hobbit remarked.

Lobelia's ears perked up. Trouble with brigands? That could be just the distraction she needed. If she could delay Bilbo's return, even by a few days, it might give her enough time to solidify her claim on Bag End.

With a wicked glint in her eye, she hurried home to hatch a new plan.

The next morning, Lobelia sent Lotho to Bree with a pouch of coins and a simple instruction: find the brigands and pay them to keep Bilbo occupied for as long as possible. Lotho, eager to please his mother, set off at once.

Days turned into weeks, and Lobelia's confidence grew. She had the will, she had the rumors, and now she had the delay. It seemed that everything was falling into place.

But she had underestimated Bilbo Baggins. The hobbit had faced trolls, goblins, and even a dragon. A few brigands in Bree were hardly a challenge for him. Bilbo dealt with them swiftly and continued on his journey home, determined to reclaim Bag End and set things right.

When he finally arrived in Hobbiton, he found his home in a state of disarray. The gardens were overgrown, the windows were dusty, and worst of all, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins was standing on the front porch, looking every bit the mistress of the house.

"What is the meaning of this?" Bilbo demanded, his voice ringing with authority.

Lobelia turned, her face a mask of feigned surprise. "Bilbo! We thought you were dead. We thought you had abandoned Bag End."

"Abandoned?" Bilbo's eyes narrowed. "I did no such thing. This is still my home, and I intend to keep it that way."

Lobelia's composure faltered for a moment, but she quickly recovered. "But we have the will, Bilbo. You left Bag End to us."

Bilbo crossed his arms over his chest. "I'd like to see this so-called will."

Lobelia hesitated, but there was no turning back now. She produced the forged document and handed it to Bilbo, her heart pounding in her chest.

Bilbo scanned the paper, his expression growing darker with each passing moment. "This is a forgery, Lobelia. I never signed this, and you know it."

Lobelia's face turned pale. "But—but everyone in Hobbiton believes it to be true. You can't just come back and take it all away."

Bilbo's eyes softened, but his resolve remained firm. "Lobelia, I understand your desire for Bag End, but this is my home. I've fought too hard and come too far to let it go. Now, I suggest you leave before I call the Bounders and have you removed."

Lobelia's pride crumbled in the face of Bilbo's determination. She knew she had been beaten. With a defeated sigh, she turned and walked away, Lotho trailing behind her.

As she left Bag End, she couldn't help but feel a twinge of regret. She had been so consumed by her desire for the grand hobbit hole that she had forgotten the true spirit of Hobbiton: community, friendship, and the simple joys of life.

Bilbo watched them go, a sense of relief washing over him. He had reclaimed his home, but more importantly, he had reaffirmed his place in the Shire. With a deep breath, he stepped inside Bag End and began the process of restoring it to its former glory.

In the weeks that followed, Bilbo worked tirelessly to repair the damage done in his absence. He tended to the gardens, polished the silver, and aired out the rooms. But he didn't do it alone. Friends and neighbors from Hobbiton came to lend a hand, eager to welcome him back and help him rebuild.

And through it all, Bilbo never lost sight of the lessons he had learned on his adventure. He had faced danger and adversity, but he had also discovered the strength of his own spirit and the value of true friendship.

One evening, as the sun set over the Shire, Bilbo sat on the porch of Bag End, a cup of tea in hand. He gazed out at the rolling hills, feeling a deep sense of contentment. He had come home, not just to a house, but to a community that cherished him.

And as for Lobelia Sackville-Baggins, she had learned a valuable lesson as well. She realized that true happiness could not be found in material possessions or grand homes, but in the simple pleasures of life and the love of family and friends.

Bilbo's return had brought more than just the restoration of Bag End. It had reminded the people of Hobbiton of the importance of kindness, generosity, and the bonds that held them together.

And so, as the stars twinkled in the night sky, Bilbo Baggins knew that he was truly home.
